params.text:
SECTION 01

Ask an Interesting Question
Supervised Learning - Biology

Machine learning algorithms can indeed function as a magic box that can perform the task without any theoretical rules. However, they can do much better if they are built with the domain knowledge in mind.
Reading 1: Predicting Drug-Protein Interactions

The ultimate question we wish to answer is: Can we predict if a drug will bind to a protein? This can be solved by using supervised learning, as we already know thousands of drug-protein interaction pairs. However, one problem persists: How should the proteins be represented?

Proteins are complex 3D molecules that cannot be described by a number, an image, or any other regular data formats. The process of identifying features of proteins and describing them with numeric data is called feature engineering, which is especially important in handling complex real-life entities like proteins.

In this Orange workflow, we aim to explore different protein features and use them to predict whether the proteins will bind to Genistein.

SECTION 02

Get the Data & Explore
Supervised Learning - Biology

Now that we have an interesting question to investigate, we will now search for the data to learn from. In this chapter, you will learn how to import data from an external source to Orange and to explore them to design your next steps.
Reading 2-1: the  ChEMBL Database

For this example, we will use the data from the ChEMBL database.

ChEMBL is a manually curated database of bioactive molecules with drug-like properties with more than 2 million compounds.

EBI stands for European Bioinformatics Institute—a subbranch of EMBL and is in charge of maintaining ChEMBL.

Genistein is a naturally occurring compound that is known to inhibit angiogenesis.

Visiting the following link will lead you to the query for Genistein in ChEBML:           Take a moment to freely explore their webpage.
Questions 2-1: the  ChEMBL Database

choices.question: What is the name of the manually curated database of bioactive molecules with drug-like properties with more than 2 million compounds?
Who is in charge of ChEMBL
answers:
European Bioinformatics Institute

Bundesministerium für Bildung und Forschung

Freie Universität Berlin

European Commission

choices.question: Which process is Genistein known to inhibit?

overallFeedback.feedback: Not bad.. but you can do better.

l10n.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.
l10n.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.

params.text:
Instructions 01:

Select “File” widget from “Data” tab and add it to the canvas.

Activity 2-1: Exploring the ChEMBL Data

In this acitivity, we will download an example data file from ChEMBL to Orange.

Instructions 02:

Double click on the File widget will open a new window. 

Copy and paste this address into URL in “Source”: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/HyunchangOh/SHK_ENKIS/master/2-1%20Explore%20Database.tsv

Instructions 03:

Clicking the door with an arrow icon with numbers 107 will open a new window where you can explore the data.

 

Take a moment to explore what kind of data you can get from the ChEMBL database.
Reading 2-2: Preprocessing the Data

The ChEMBL database contains a lot of information, but we do not need all of them. The authors of this article, Atas et al., extracted only the information we need and processed them to give them the right format for training.

• The number of known targets of Genistein is too small for training a robust model. The authors searched for more molecules that are similar enough to the known targets and included them as well in the training data.

• The activity of the targets, or the strength of their interaction with Genistein, is denoted as integer values. The authors changed this to a binary yes or no value by setting a specific cutoff value.
Questions 2-2: Preprocessing the Data

choices.question: How did the authors deal with the problem that there are too few targets of Genistein for training?
answers:
They searched for similar molecules.

They conducted extra experiments.

They computationally created similar structures.

They included targets of drugs that are similar to Genistein.

choices.question: What values did the acitivity of the targets have?
How did the authors transform the activity of the targets to give them Boolean values, that is True or False?
answers:
By setting a specific cutoff value.

By taking the negative values as False and positive values as True.

By ranking them from strongest-interacting to weakest-interacting

By wet experiments

overallFeedback.feedback: Not bad.. but you can do better.

params.text:
Instructions 01:

Select “File” widget from “Data” tab and add it to the canvas.

Activity 2-2: Downloading Train and Test Data

In this acitivity, we will download the data which have been preprocessed from ChEMBL database by the authors. The data have already been split into test and train data, so we will download two separate files.

Instructions 02:

As in section 2-1. add a new ‘File’ widget and add the following URL as the source. This will download the test data.

https://raw.githubusercontent.com/HyunchangOh/SHK_ENKIS/master/chembl44_test_fold1.tsv

Instructions 03:

Note that the file has only two columns: Bioactivity denotes weather each protein binds to Genistein and target_id is used to identify each protein and link it to its features later.

Instructions 04:

Add another File widget and add the following URL to the source. This contains the train data. 

https://raw.githubusercontent.com/HyunchangOh /SHK_ENKIS/master/chembl44_train_fold1.tsv

Instructions 05:

The train data has the same format to the test data, just with different proteins.

SECTION 03

Feature Engineering
Supervised Learning - Biology

In the data we have now, the proteins are described as their id only, which doesn't tell us much about their structural/chemical properties. As briefly discussed in Section 1, we need to devise a method to describe the intricate properties of the molecules as fully as possible in a way that is understandable by computers.
Reading 3-1: Feature Engineering

How should we represent, or describe the molecules?

In the data we have now, the proteins are described as their id only, which doesn't tell us much about their structural/chemical properties. As briefly discussed in Section 1, we need to devise a method to describe the intricate properties of the molecules as fully as possible in a way that is understandable by computers.

Instructions 01:

Make a new File widget and give the following URL to the source.

https://raw.githubusercontent.com/HyunchangOh/ SHK_ENKIS/master/feature_vectors/aac.tsv

Activity 3-1: Exploring Feature Vectors

In this acitivity, we will import and explore the aac (Amino Acid Composition) descriptor, which shows the proportion of each amino acid in the protein.

Instructions 02:

Double click on the added File widget to explore the data. Cotemplate on what each column may mean.
Questions 3: Feature Engineering

choices.question: What best describes the process of feature engineering?
answers:
the process to select or design variables to extract the most important properties of the real-life objects to be learned by the model

the process to fine-tune the parameters of the model to optimize its performance

the process to select the input data from which the model will learn

the process to make feedback from the model's output values into the input

choices.question: What do each symbol in 'Name' column of the 'aac' feature vector that we loaded in the previous instruction?
answers:
Amino Acids

Indices

Each Alphabet in the name of the protein target

ID for each protein target

overallFeedback.feedback: Not bad.. but you can do better.

params.text:
SECTION 04

Model the Data
Supervised Learning - Biology
You have come far. Now is the time to create a model that will learn from our input to make accurate predictions on unseen data.
Reading 4: Support Vector Machine

Among many supervised learning techniques, we will use the one called "SVM", or "Support Vector Machine" that is, in simple terms, a smart boundary drawing algorithm.

Imagine you have a set of data points belonging to two different classes and you want to draw a line (or a plane in higher dimensions) to separate these classes as clearly as possible. SVM helps you find the best possible line that maximizes the margin (distance) between the closest points of each class. These closest points are called support vectors.

What makes SVM special is its ability to handle complex datasets by transforming the input space into a higher-dimensional space, where it becomes easier to find a separating hyperplane. This transformation is done using a mathematical function called a kernel.
Questions 4: Support Vector Machine

choices.question: What does SVM stand for?
answers:
Support Vector Machine

System Vector Multiplication

Sequential Voting Method

Space Vector Modulation

choices.question: What is the primary objective of Support Vector Machines (SVM) in classification tasks?
answers:
Maximize the margin between the decision boundary and the support vectors

Find the centroid of each class in the dataset

Reduce the dimensionality of the feature spaceEach Alphabet in the name of the protein target

Minimize the number of misclassified data points

choices.question: What is SVM used for?
answers:
Classification and Regression

Classification, but not Regression

Regression, but not Classification

Not ideal for either of Regression or Classification

overallFeedback.feedback: Not bad.. but you can do better.

params.text:
Instructions 01:

First we will use the “Merge Data” widget to link the train data to our feature data. Add the widget and drag from each of the File widgets to the Merge Data widget.

Activity 4-1: Exploring Feature Vectors

In this acitivity, we will create a SVM model to learn from the input data we imported in earlier sections.

Instructions 02:

Double click on the Merge Data widget. Notice the ‘Row matching’ part: rows with the same target_id will be merged so that each row will contain all the features (amino acid compositions) and the binary bioactivity from the train dataset.

Instructions 03:

We will then use ‘Select Columns’ widget to specify the target of prediction. Add the widget and drag from Merge Data widget to the Select Columns widget.

Instructions 04:

All of the columns will be used as the basis of prediction and bioactivity will be marked as ‘Target’.

Instructions 05:

Add the ‘SVM’ widget from the ‘Model’ tab. Link it to the Select Columns widget.

Instructions 06:

Double click to see the hyperparameters of our model. We will leave them as the default setting.

Instructions 07:

Now we will merge test and feature data, just like we did with train data.

Instructions 08:

Do not forget to check that the match is done from target_id to target_id.

Instructions 09:

We will use ‘Select Rows’ widget this time to deal with undefined values.

Instructions 10:

There is no point of using the rows with undefined bioactivity, when it is the target of our prediction. Select ‘bioactivity’ and ‘is defined’ to select only the rows with defined bioactivity value.

Instructions 11:

Then we will use “Select Columns” widget again to specify the target of prediction.

Instructions 12:

Same as with train data, set ‘bioactivity’ as the target, target_id as Metas, and all others as ‘features’

Instructions 13:

Now is the time to test how well our SVM model can predict. Add “Predictions” widget from “Evaluate” tab and link it with the two previous sub-branches of the workflow. We will interpret the results in the next section.

SECTION 05

Communicate the Results
Supervised Learning - Biology

Congratulations on building your SVM model! However, we do not know if the model actually makes good predictions and even if it does, how good are these predictions? To communicate the performance of your model, we need to know the metrics to evalute the model.
Reading 5: Evaluation Metrics

Here are some metrics that Orange supports to evalute a model.

Accuracy: Of all the predictions we made, how many were correct?

Precision: Of all the positive predictions we made, how many were correct?

Recall: Of all the predictions that should have been positive, how many did we got correct?

f1-score: A score that combines precision and recall that is 1 for a perfect model and 0 for a terrible model.

MCC: Stands for Mathew's Correlation Coefficient, also called Phi coefficient. Another combined score that is also 1 for a perfect model and 0 for a terrible model.

Instructions 01:

Double clicking on the “Predictions” widget will open up the report window. You can see what the model predicted for each individual protein from test data and also how ‘sure’ the model was with each prediction.

At the bottom of the window there are several evaluation metrics to show how good the prediction was overall

Activity 5: Evaluating the Model

After making predictions, we can use them to evaluate our model. Orange gives such information directly from the "Predictions" widget.
Questions 5: Evaluating the Model

choices.question: Which of the following best fits the description? Of all the predictions we made, how many were correct?
Which of the following best fits the description? Of all the positive predictions we made, how many were correct?
Which of the following best fits the description? Of all the predictions that should have been positive, how many did we got correct?
Which of the following best fits the description? A score that combines precision and recall that is 1 for a perfect model and 0 for a terrible model.
Which of the following is the closest to the Precision of our model?

overallFeedback.feedback: Not bad.. but you can do better.
